response.answer_text: It depends on your personal situation a bit. However, I’d strongly caution you to pay off the balance each month, and not run up balances, even at lower interest rates. Don’t spend, or if you must, use a line of credit. For credit cards, my favorites are: Fidelity: they have several cards that offer 2% back, and the money goes to 529 accounts or your brokerage account (but you can withdraw it). 2% on all purchases, not bad.American Express Cash Builder: 1% on all purchases refunded. 3% at gas stations and department stores. 6% at grocery stores (up to $6,000 per year). Use this one only at gas stations, department stores or grocery stores.Chase Freedom: 5% rebates on a few categories each quarter. It can be restaurants, gas stations, department stores, Amazon, Walmart, etc. There’s usually two or three categories per quarter. Useful only for the categories, otherwise you get 1%.Now, while I travel some for business, I go to places where I can’t always take the same airline. So frequent flyer miles or Starwood points aren’t that useful for me. I’d rather have the cash back. But if you live in Atlanta and fly a lot for business, might make sense to get a Delta Skymiles Visa card (or whatever it’s called). The miles might be better than cash back for you. Sometimes there are Visa or Mastercards tied to a single merchant where you get 3% back at that store. I don’t bother because it’s not really worth the effort to remember to pay it because I use those so infrequently. I get 2% minimum with the fidelity card, so that 1% on $150 purchased a year just isn’t worth the effort. But if you shop at that store a lot, might be worth it. For a while, car companies offered x% back for a new car purchase. If you knew you were going to buy one of those cars (and a new car), might be worth it. I don’t work for a credit card company, and never have. This is just based on my use of the cards. Biggest thing to remember: don’t carry a balance.

Credit card companies are the financial institutions (in most cases, banks) that issue credit cards to consumers and service their accounts. American Express is also known for being the world’s largest issuer of charge cards and for targeting its products to high-income individuals with strong credit scores. As a result, Amex is a great source of lucrative rewards credit cards, but is not heavily involved in the credit improvement space. It is interesting to note, however, that Amex has in recent years partnered with Walmart to introduce the Bluebird Prepaid Card, the company’s first foray into the growing prepaid card market and seemingly an attempt to expand its consumer reach. Bank of America is not only one of the largest financial institutions in the world, but one of the largest companies as well. Headquartered in Charlotte, NC, the banking behemoth now has nearly 300,000 full-time employees and does $100+ billion in annual revenue. Barclaycard, the payment card business of London-based banking giant Barclays, was the first UK credit card program when it was introduced in 1966. Barclaycard US was established in 2004, when Barclays purchased U.S.-based Juniper Financial Corporation. Capital One is the 5th largest U.S. credit card company in terms of both outstanding balances and purchase volume. The company, established in 1995, is based in McLean, VA and has around 1,000 branch locations in the District of Columbia, Louisiana, Maryland, New York, New Jersey, Texas, and Virginia. In addition to credit cards, Capital One is known for offering everyday banking products, personal loans, and auto loans. You do not necessarily need a credit card to build credit. Credit is actually “lines of credit” and payments made over a period of time. Therefore, it is simply your management of debt and how well you can manage your finances according to pre-defined rules. You can begin by going to a bank and establishing a bank account if you have not already done so. Once completed, ask to open a secured line of credit, which is simply a credit card, issues from the funds in your actual bank account. Since the banks are establishing a credit line, they are required to report this information, as well as because they make a profit from this. You can do this as many times as you want. Rule of thumb, use only 10% or less of the balance on the card per month. So if you have a phone bill of $50, you will need $500 in credit to keep things at a 10% maximum use. Do this with 4–7 cards and in 2 years you will have close to an 800 score or possibly even go over the 800 mark which is excellent credit. This is provided that you are not behind on other obligations like loans, etc. You can also get loans that you pay off over time, like a deferred payment plan on laptops, furniture, etc. The reason I suggest your own line of credit is also the fact that it’s your money so if you spend it all, there’s no debt to repay. You simply have nothing left in your account. Good luck.
